11.02.text:
It’s now been a year since the tragic death
of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri.

16.89.text:
His death—along with the events in Cleveland,
Staten Island, Baltimore, Cincinnati, and

22.06.text:
other communities—sparked protests and soul
searching all across our country.

26.70.text:
Over the past year, we’ve come to see, more
clearly than ever, the frustration in many

31.21.text:
communities of color and the feeling that
our laws can be applied unevenly.

37.54.text:
After Ferguson, I said that we had to face
these issues squarely.

40.51.text:
I convened a task force on community policing
to find commonsense steps that can help us

45.73.text:
drive down crime and build up trust and cooperation
between communities and police, who put their

51.96.text:
lives on the line every single day to help
keep us safe.

54.92.text:
And I’ve met personally with rank and file
officers to hear their ideas.

59.88.text:
In May, this task force made up of police
officers, activists and academics proposed

67.75.text:
59 recommendations – everything from how
we can make better use of data and technology,

73.64.text:
to how we train police officers, to how law
enforcement engages with our schools.

77.84.text:
And we’ve been working with communities
across America to put these ideas into action.

83.13.text:
Dozens of police departments are now sharing
more data with the public, including on citations,

88.13.text:
stops and searches, and shootings involving
law enforcement.

91.66.text:
We’ve brought together leaders from across
the country to explore alternatives to incarceration.

97.64.text:
The Justice Department has begun pilot programs
to help police use body cameras and collect

102.05.text: data on the use of force.

104.53.text:
This fall, the department will award more
than $160 million in grants to support law

108.93.text:
enforcement and community organizations that
are working to improve policing.

114.27.text:
And all across the country – from states
like Illinois and Ohio, to cities like Philadelphia,

118.88.text:
Boston, and Nashville – local leaders are
working to implement the task force recommendations

124.67.text: in a way that works for their communities.

130.42.text:
But let’s be clear: the issues raised over
the past year aren’t new, and they won’t

137.85.text:
We simply can’t ask our police to contain
and control issues that the rest of us aren’t

145.45.text:
That starts with reforming a criminal justice
system that too often is a pipeline from inadequate

150.13.text:
schools to overcrowded jails, wreaking havoc
on communities and families all across the

155.71.text:
So we need Congress to reform our federal
sentencing laws for non-violent drug offenders.

160.86.text:
We need to keep working to help more prisoners
take steps to turn their lives around so they

165.64.text:
can contribute to their communities after
they’ve served their time.

169.89.text:
More broadly, we need to truly invest in our
children and our communities so that more

174.92.text: young people see a better path for their lives.

177.25.text:
That means investing in early childhood education,
job training, pathways to college.

183.57.text:
It means dealing honestly with issues of race,
poverty, and class that leave too many communities

188.67.text:
feeling isolated and segregated from greater
opportunity.

192.76.text:
It means expanding that opportunity to every
American willing to work for it, no matter

197.20.text: what zip code they were born into.

199.09.text:
Because, in the end, that’s always been
the promise of America.

203.02.text:
And that’s what I’ll keep working for
every single day that I’m President.

207.64.text: Thanks everybody, and have a great weekend.
